He can explain the character of Norman Bates rationally, but he cannot make our response to his story and its effect on us feel ultimately safe, feel somehow in control and finalized. Yes, one can put people like Norman under the microscope, and even dissect what one sees, but this doesn't stop such events as unfolded in the movie any less likely to occur. Ask Milton Arbogast.

In conclusion I'd like to say that great films are made up of outstanding little things, not just big moments or fancy effects. There is in fact nothing fancy about Psycho, which is on the surface is a somewhat plain-looking movie. Only when one looks beneath the surface does one see the teeming millions of small things,--gestures, glances, sudden changes in lighting, razor-sharp editing, and all above the refusal on the part of the director to let any one factor dominate--that we understand the meaning of the word genius, the meaning of the word creative.

Title: Overall good Hitchcock movie
Review:
So much has been written about this film that all I can do is add my own voice of approval and say that I consider it to be a masterpiece, and add a few things often overlooked or not commented on that add so much to the movie's cumulative power. It's often the little things that make a film work. Here are a few examples:

a.) The absolute realism of the first twenty minutes of so, which are so true to life that they might have come from a documentary on how people lived in America forty years ago. There isn't a false note,--or a missed one--as each vocal inflection and raised eyebrow carries great meaning even if, on the surface, not much appears to be happening.

b.) Marion and the motorcycle cop. The cop is dark and sinister in appearance, due mostly to the bright desert sun, and never takes off his sunglasses. His conduct is at all times professional; he never raises his voice, and comes across as calm and rather perceptive; and he seems truly concerned over Marion Crane's fate, though he is unaware of her actual predicament. Marion is, alas, a bad actress, and the cop sees through this, if not to the heart of the matter, yet we don't want him to follow her. Despite his appearance the cop is not the angel of death but rather Marion's last chance. Had she confessed to her crime she would have escaped the fate that awaited her; and if she had just been a little less clever, and driven more slowly, and the skies remained clear, he might have followed her to the motel and intervened on her behalf.

c.) California Charlie. John Anderson is wonderful as the fast-talking, semi-streetwise small town used car salesman. At the end of almost every other line of dialogue he seems on the verge of discovering who Marion really is, then pulls back or comes to the wrong conclusion. He senses that she is being watched by the cop; but he also wants to make a sale. The scenes at the used car lot are both highly realistic,--and perfectly acted and timed--and also a little frightening, from the opening, "I'm in no mood for trouble", to the final "hey!" just before Marion drives away. We know that something isn't right, but the problem isn't with the car lot; it's Marion's plight casts a dark shadow over all her scenes there, despite the brightest sunlight imaginable.

d.) Chitchat with Norman. Once Marion and Norman settle down for a light meal in the parlor their conversation turns to general things, and Norman is a good observer, if a bit awkward socially. Without actually lying Marion gives herself away with a throwaway line ("Sometimes just once is enough", in a reference to private traps) and Norman seems to catch her drift, if not the actual meaning of what she's saying, and allows it to pass. We can see that he is moody when he angrily leans forward and delivers an angry, though controlled tirade against putting people in institutions. Every camera angle and line of dialogue in this scene has meaning and carries enormous weight, and yet the drama plays out in a light, relaxed mode, and the performers seems truly connected to one another at its conclusion, strangers no more. This is in my opinion the best written and most beautifully acted, edited and photographed scene I have ever seen in a movie. The handling of every nuance is prodigal and masterful, and the end result nothing less than staggering.

e.) The sheriff's house. When Sam and Lila wake up the sheriff and his wife in the middle of the night we see a splendid example of people talking to one another without either party understanding what is in fact going on. The result is a mini-comedy of manners; but it is also good exposition, as we learn of Mrs. Bates' death (and the dress she was buried in, "periwinkle blue"). John McInyre's sheriff dominates this scene (and no other), and expertly delivers its punchline, "Well if that's Mrs. Bates in the window, who's that buried up in Greenlawn Cemetary".

f.) Arbogast and Norman. The private detective's interview with Norman is played low-key, and yet we sense the tension in Norman's voice and manner, and know that Arbogast does, too. Something is amiss. This is beyond the question of who killed Marion. The stakes feel very high in this sparring match, and though Norman wins on a technicality, we know that Arbogast is coming back for more.

g.) The shrink's explanation. This part of the film has been criticized by many for being a sop thrown to the audience. I disagree. After all, the movie came out in 1960, and by the standards of the time some explanation seems in order, and Dr. Simon Oakland is as good a man for the job as I can imagine. His analysis of Norman's pathology is cogent and extremely well delivered. Yet throughout his speech, with all its Freudian brilliance, the doctor offered a take on the story that we in the audience, even if we can accept it, can never be satisfied with. He can explain the character of Norman Bates rationally, but he cannot make our response to his story and its effect on us feel ultimately safe, feel somehow in control and finalized. Yes, one can put people like Norman under the microscope, and even dissect what one sees, but this doesn't stop such events as unfolded in the movie any less likely to occur. Ask Milton Arbogast.

In conclusion I'd like to say that great films are made up of outstanding little things, not just big moments or fancy effects. There is in fact nothing fancy about Psycho, which is on the surface is a somewhat plain-looking movie. Only when one looks beneath the surface does one see the teeming millions of small things,--gestures, glances, sudden changes in lighting, razor-sharp editing, and all above the refusal on the part of the director to let any one factor dominate--that we understand the meaning of the word genius, the meaning of the word creative.

Title: a masterpiece of a film
Review:
i first saw this film many years ago. I think it is one of the best films i have ever seen. I think it still stands up in our age and will for along time to come. The tension in the film is remarkable, this film was ahead of its time and many directors have seen this film and it would have inspired them like it has inspired me. AlfredHitchcockhis the best director of all time. He has made some of the best films of all time including rear window, vertigo, strangers on a train and the birds too name but a few. I would like to say that Alfred Hitchcock has changed my outlook on life and i will carry on watching his films for along time to come. One last thing is that the best film he ever directed is vertigo in my opinion.

Title: Aesthetics
Review:
Psycho is more than another horror film. Every minute of this movie is dedicated to guiding the audience in a certain direction and playing on expectations. The incredible style in which it was shot was monumental and taboo for the day. Through the brilliant editing, controlled releasing of information and camera techniques Hitchcock was successfully able to create a classic horror movie. What truly separates Psycho is from other horror movies, including today's horror movies, is the element of surprise and importance on a solid well-written script. Once a solid story was created Hitchcock made Psycho a visual work of art that upholds today as one of the best horror films to date.

Title: maybe too scared?
Review:
I rented this movie for my friends birthday party this weekend. We LOVE scary movies. . they're the only things we watch whenever we have parties. but we're only. . . 14. . 15. i've read about how good this movie is from all the reviews that you guys wrote. but its rated R. . so maybe its TOO scary? i mean.. . i was reading this Alfred Hitchcock biography that my friend had. . and there was this picture of mothers corpse on their and nearly scared me to death. so i know everybody loves this movie and its the greatest horror flick of all time. but do you think its too scary for us to handle? and i know the shower scene is. . infamous. . but did any of you guys dread taking showers after watching that scene in the movie? knowing me. . i'll probably stink up the whole school because i'll be scared to death. so will we have nightmares. . forever?

Title: The quintessential psychological thriller. Magic.
Review:
"Psycho" is the ultimate suspense film. The plot is superbly developed and exhilaratingly full of psychological manipulation. It is without any hum-our - voluntary or involuntary - whatsoever, but this only adds to the clarity and starkness of the story, and above all of the images. They stick to your retina and stay lodged in your brain for ever - resemblant of "Potemkin" - but without the stills effect. And to round it off, the real mark of excellence: a brilliant ending. I remember coming out of the movie theater after seeing "Psycho" for the first time, at the age of 16. I was devastated. Drained. I instinctively knew there was something deeply truthful in this film. Just like "The Silence of the Lambs". Disturbing - but absolutely credible. Which - of course - would not have been possible without good actors. So turn off the lights, shut out the world around you, and I can guarantee you will be sucked into this "flick".

There is in fact nothing fancy about Psycho, which is on the surface is a somewhat plain-looking movie. Only when one looks beneath the surface does one see the teeming millions of small things,--gestures, glances, sudden changes in lighting, razor-sharp editing, and all above the refusal on the part of the director to let any one factor dominate--that we understand the meaning of the word genius, the meaning of the word creative.

Title: Easily the greatest Slasher film ever
Review:
So much has been written about this film that all I can do is add my own voice of approval and say that I consider it to be a masterpiece, and add a few things often overlooked or not commented on that add so much to the movie's cumulative power. It's often the little things that make a film work. Here are a few examples:

a.) The absolute realism of the first twenty minutes of so, which are so true to life that they might have come from a documentary on how people lived in America forty years ago. There isn't a false note,--or a missed one--as each vocal inflection and raised eyebrow carries great meaning even if, on the surface, not much appears to be happening.

b.) Marion and the motorcycle cop. The cop is dark and sinister in appearance, due mostly to the bright desert sun, and never takes off his sunglasses. His conduct is at all times professional; he never raises his voice, and comes across as calm and rather perceptive; and he seems truly concerned over Marion Crane's fate, though he is unaware of her actual predicament. Marion is, alas, a bad actress, and the cop sees through this, if not to the heart of the matter, yet we don't want him to follow her. Despite his appearance the cop is not the angel of death but rather Marion's last chance. Had she confessed to her crime she would have escaped the fate that awaited her; and if she had just been a little less clever, and driven more slowly, and the skies remained clear, he might have followed her to the motel and intervened on her behalf.

c.) California Charlie. John Anderson is wonderful as the fast-talking, semi-streetwise small town used car salesman. At the end of almost every other line of dialogue he seems on the verge of discovering who Marion really is, then pulls back or comes to the wrong conclusion. He senses that she is being watched by the cop; but he also wants to make a sale. The scenes at the used car lot are both highly realistic,--and perfectly acted and timed--and also a little frightening, from the opening, "I'm in no mood for trouble", to the final "hey!" just before Marion drives away. We know that something isn't right, but the problem isn't with the car lot; it's Marion's plight casts a dark shadow over all her scenes there, despite the brightest sunlight imaginable.

d.) Chitchat with Norman. Once Marion and Norman settle down for a light meal in the parlor their conversation turns to general things, and Norman is a good observer, if a bit awkward socially. Without actually lying Marion gives herself away with a throwaway line ("Sometimes just once is enough", in a reference to private traps) and Norman seems to catch her drift, if not the actual meaning of what she's saying, and allows it to pass. We can see that he is moody when he angrily leans forward and delivers an angry, though controlled tirade against putting people in institutions. Every camera angle and line of dialogue in this scene has meaning and carries enormous weight, and yet the drama plays out in a light, relaxed mode, and the performers seems truly connected to one another at its conclusion, strangers no more. This is in my opinion the best written and most beautifully acted, edited and photographed scene I have ever seen in a movie. The handling of every nuance is prodigal and masterful, and the end result nothing less than staggering.

e.) The sheriff's house. When Sam and Lila wake up the sheriff and his wife in the middle of the night we see a splendid example of people talking to one another without either party understanding what is in fact going on. The result is a mini-comedy of manners; but it is also good exposition, as we learn of Mrs. Bates' death (and the dress she was buried in, "periwinkle blue"). John McInyre's sheriff dominates this scene (and no other), and expertly delivers its punchline, "Well if that's Mrs. Bates in the window, who's that buried up in Greenlawn Cemetary".

f.) Arbogast and Norman. The private detective's interview with Norman is played low-key, and yet we sense the tension in Norman's voice and manner, and know that Arbogast does, too. Something is amiss. This is beyond the question of who killed Marion. The stakes feel very high in this sparring match, and though Norman wins on a technicality, we know that Arbogast is coming back for more.

g.) The shrink's explanation. This part of the film has been criticized by many for being a sop thrown to the audience. I disagree. After all, the movie came out in 1960, and by the standards of the time some explanation seems in order, and Dr. Simon Oakland is as good a man for the job as I can imagine. His analysis of Norman's pathology is cogent and extremely well delivered. Yet throughout his speech, with all its Freudian brilliance, the doctor offered a take on the story that we in the audience, even if we can accept it, can never be satisfied with. He can explain the character of Norman Bates rationally, but he cannot make our response to his story and its effect on us feel ultimately safe, feel somehow in control and finalized. Yes, one can put people like Norman under the microscope, and even dissect what one sees, but this doesn't stop such events as unfolded in the movie any less likely to occur. Ask Milton Arbogast.

In conclusion I'd like to say that great films are made up of outstanding little things, not just big moments or fancy effects. There is in fact nothing fancy about Psycho, which is on the surface is a somewhat plain-looking movie. Only when one looks beneath the surface does one see the teeming millions of small things,--gestures, glances, sudden changes in lighting, razor-sharp editing, and all above the refusal on the part of the director to let any one factor dominate--that we understand the meaning of the word genius, the meaning of the word creative.

Title: Scariest and best movie i've ever seen
Review:
I was not even a gleam in my father's eye when this movie was made, and yet this movie is as scary now as I'm sure it was then. "Scary" movies these days generally do not scare me at all. Alfred Hitchcock's movies have always had an uncanny ability to scare the wits out of me. Particular Vertigo and this movie. The Birds was scary also, but not as disturbing as these. Now, about this review. I had never seen this before and on a boring Saturday evening I decided to go buy this dvd from the local store. So, I got it and watched it that night. I watched it with the lights out, my surround system cranked, and on the edge of my seat the whole time. I cannot tell you how many times my heart skipped a beat in this movie. The music, the photography, the lighting, everything combined to make this a movie that I will not forget. The music in the shower scene that is repeated at the very end (screeching violins) is forever engrained in my memory. I tried watching this movie again by myself today and I cannot do it. That is how scary it is. Anthony Perkins is amazing. Everyone in the cast is amazing, but his is the performance that you will remember from this movie.

Now, about the dvd. This dvd is incredible. A 90-minute making of Psycho is incredible. There is also a trailer, another documentary, and tons of other good stuff. They really crammed a lot onto this dvd to make it worth your money. The video quality is crystal clear. The audio quality is stupendous. It is only Dolby Digital stereo though. Just be sure to crank this one to let Bernard Herrmanns score scare you out of your mind. To sum it up, do not rent this dvd, this dvd belongs in your collection so do yourself a favor and go rent it. But do not watch it by yourself unless you are brave.

Title: Excellent
Review:
This is by far Alfred Hitchcocks greatest film of his career, and that is something very special.

Anyway you must see this film, if you have not seen it then where have you been for the last 4 decades. An absolute classic.

Title: clever alternate soundtrack
Review:
I just found this online. This group called Jokr has released a 2CD album of music that they call PSYCHOsync. It's supposed to be a synchronized match-up with Alfred Hitchcock's "Psycho" with their own music replacing Bernard Herrmann's original score. Of course, Herrmann's soundtrack is classic, iconic and could not be improved upon, but this haunting pop music wrings out different story lines and emotion than what is evident in the original. It reminds me of what they say you can do with Pink Floyd's "Dark Side of the Moon" and "The Wizard of Oz." You can check out their music streaming at jokrcode dot com.

Title: the best film EVER!
Review:
This is without a doubt the best film i've ever seen, it never fails to scare me and it has the best and most chilling plot ever. Hitchcock's finest hour, not only his best film, but the best film ever made! it has some of the most classic scenes that has have been imitated but never mastered, the shower scene everybody knows, even if you haven't seen the movie, the absolutely terrifying final scenes in the fruit cellar is perfect horror. Anthony Perkins is so brilliant in the role that you will never be rid of the image of the character that is Norman bates, Janet Leigh, Vera Miles and John Gavin are also brilliant and create a tense atmosphere that really chills you. 100% movie making.

Title: The Greatest Movie Ever Made!!!!!!(in my opinion, anyway)
Review:
I love this movie!!! It's my all-time absolute favorite movie in the entire world! I have seen this movie approximately 20 - 25 times and it still scares the crap out of me! No one, but no one, BUT ANTHONY PERKINS could ever be Norman Bates. Alfred Hitchcock is perhaps the best director and filmmaker in history! His films are the films which inspire young people like myself to become filmmakers, and film historians, and Hitchcock scholars, and to choose many other film careers. It's just beyond my ability to express my love for this movie. This was the first Hitchcock film I had ever seen, and will remain my favorite film for the rest of my life. I even have the soundtrack! Best movie in the world, a little cheesy by today's standards but who cares, it will make you grip the edge of your seat and your eyes pop out. SEE IT! YOU WILL LOVE IT!!!!!!

Title: Thank you, Hitch
Review:
I saw Psycho for the first time when I was seventeen; I saw it for the second time in August 2001. By that time, nothing has been the same. I love Psycho because of two main reasons: 1) in this movie you will find the best shots and the best way of directing of the cinema history; 2)Psycho is best and the easiest way to describe the human being: dreams, nightmares, hopes, obsessions, fears, wills. I'll always be grateful to Hitch for this movie: thank you, Alfred. P.S. Thanks also to Bernard Herrmann, for his dreadful but wonderful soundtrack ("the screaming violins") and to the unforgettable Norman Perkins for his interpretation of the great Norman Bates. You'll always have a special place in my heart.

Title: Classic Horror Film
Review:
This is an excellent horror film. However it does not contain a lot of gore nor is it particularly scary. It is suspenseful and has an interesting twist in the plot. The music and sound effects are well done. The black and white doesn't take anything away from the film at all. The film is perfectly named as the main character is about as nuts as you can get. The overall acting was good. The few violent scenes looked pretty cheesy, but for its time not horrible. Would recommend this film to any level of viewer from newbie all the way to movie buff. I read that this was based on Ed Gein lightly, same as Texas chainsaw massacre and Silence of the Lambs.

Title: The Ultimate Movie
Review:
A near perfect film that few today can see in its intended state, ie not knowing anything about it! Hitch masterfully lulls is into thinking the film will be about a girl who takes off with a load of money - yet that has no relevance to the film in the slightest (other than to scare the hell out of you when she dies). I actually watched this film not knowing that Norman Bates was his mother and ultimately gained more from the film than a lot of people that I know have watched it. Perfect score to the film by Bernard Herrmann which adds to the tension - see especially the music as marion is driving in the rain, and note how the windscreen wipers are a metaphor for the knife the rain is also used like the water from the shower (almost hinting at what will follow) Superb film from the master of suspense! 10/10

Title: Psycho 1960
Review:
The original screening of "Psycho" was released at the former (untitled) Westwood theatre at Pico and Westwood Blvd. in Westwood California, (since than that theatre has been replaced by the Westwood Mall.) A selected invitational viewing was privately projected for the guests, cast and crew prior to it's release. As an undisclosed surreptitiously disguised Hitchcock enigma, this version was edited with a subliminal avant-garde inclusion of a craftily illustrated "Skull and Crossbones symbol" and spliced into the film after every nine frames of the shower and detective's butchering scenes. Whether or not once the film industry's critics discovered and banned this effect and allowed Hitchcock to continue projecting this version extensively was unknown, but by the time this well-scripted "Psycho" was publicly released the fear factor had already been commonly reputed. The silence, suspended action, proceeded by the dramatic music, and the aerial jump cut filming made it a sleepless producing journey of celluloid-fanaticism.

After attending this private screening I was scared out of my innocent mind. A few weeks proceeded and upon it's release to the local theaters, rumor had it that the shrewd Hitchcock created some hanky-panky with this film, so we examined the reel from our local theater's projection room, and discovered the subconscious inclusion of his secret confidential editing. Due to the critical film industry's mere political influence, Hitchcock had to remove this phenomenal strategy. By its reputation alone since "Nosferatu," "Psycho" had already stood patented as the most horrifying visual experience ever. "Psycho" really didn't need any editing enhancement. Viewing it again recently still sends chills through my skin!

The psychiatrist at the climax of this film played a key role and scene of it's finale who explained the events of the nature of what took place at this spine-tingling escapade.

The geniuses of Alfred Hitchcock and Anthony Perkins will not be forgotten...may they Rest In Peace.

Title: My favorite movie
Review:
Exceptional movie. I'm a particular fan of horrors, but I hate the ones that are all gore and no plot. Psycho has hardly any gore, but got me yelling with satisfying fright.

Black and white really works with this movie. It's easier to see ominous shadows and I was tense the whole time, on the alert for flickering shapes. The images were beautifully taped. The plot is complex and very thought-provoking, and went along well with my love for all things psychology.

My favorite movie changes nearly monthly, but this is definitely going to be my favorite for a long while. Shortly after seeing it, I couldn't stop thinking about it and I researched my favorite scenes on Youtube and made my computer desktop a picture of Norman Bates.

Only Hitchcock could have made such a great film!

Title: Ageless Masterpiece
Review:
This is an ageless movie and unquestionably one of the best one that Hitchcock has ever created.

Yet throughout his speech, with all its Freudian brilliance, the doctor offered a take on the story that we in the audience, even if we can accept it, can never be satisfied with. He can explain the character of Norman Bates rationally, but he cannot make our response to his story and its effect on us feel ultimately safe, feel somehow in control and finalized. Yes, one can put people like Norman under the microscope, and even dissect what one sees, but this doesn't stop such events as unfolded in the movie any less likely to occur. Ask Milton Arbogast.

In conclusion I'd like to say that great films are made up of outstanding little things, not just big moments or fancy effects. There is in fact nothing fancy about Psycho, which is on the surface is a somewhat plain-looking movie. Only when one looks beneath the surface does one see the teeming millions of small things,--gestures, glances, sudden changes in lighting, razor-sharp editing, and all above the refusal on the part of the director to let any one factor dominate--that we understand the meaning of the word genius, the meaning of the word creative.

Title: Greatest thriller of all time
Review: Never before has a director captivated an audience more than when Alfred Hitchcock did it with the release of his 1960 film, `Psycho'. This film starring Janet Leigh and Anthony Perkins attracted never-ending lines at the box office and sent the viewers home fearing for their own lives. `Psycho', which is referred to by Robin Wood as `perhaps the most terrifying film ever made' did not become a classic because it is an excellent shocker, but because it contains immensely deep themes, images and ideas that came together perfectly. This is a film that will never be duplicated, not even by the great Gus Van Sant. There are many elements that fused together to make this film the ideal horror film of all time. One major component that was essential to the effectiveness of `Psycho' was the casting. Janet Leigh plays the typical 1950's bombshell. She is calm, reserved, and very lady-like. However she shares something in common with almost all the other characters in this movie. Like her coworker with her tranquilizers, her boss with his bottle of whiskey, Cassidy with his tax-evading ways, and Norman with the obvious twist, Merion has a secret. She is involved in a sexual relationship with a man that is deeply in debt. This ultimately leads to her stealing the money and winding up in a disastrous situation. To the audience Leigh represents a good-looking version of an everyday American woman, letting the audience know that this kind of thing can happen to anybody. Norman Bates, played by Anthony Perkins is also perfectly cast. He is a very sensitive, vulnerable, and nervous character. He also seems to be stuck between boyhood and manhood, which is evident from his messy room and sworn allegiance to his mother. Together with Leigh, the two are able to create the friction and tension that is so evident throughout the entire movie. This was something that Van Sant was unable to do by casting Anne Heche and Vince Vaughn in the same roles. Heche has been a very controversial figure in the public eye over the last few years. As a result, the audience is unable to pick up the same sense of guilt that was so beautifully displayed by Leigh. Vaughn as well may have performed well in the role, however he was clearly not meant for it. One cannot simply jump from being a `swinger' to being a reserved, childish momma's boy. One of the many themes of `Psycho' is the idea that this sort of thing can happen to anybody. This is seen in the opening shot where the camera is weaving through the city, and randomly chooses a hotel room of a random high rise building. There we see two young lovers doing something that is for the most part human, although not ethical at this point in history. Merion the pockets a little cash to help her boyfriend get out of debt, so they could proceed to have a happy life together. Once again, although it is not ethical, it is not unheard of. On her way out of Phoenix Merion experiences some turbulent weather, forcing her to pull off to the side of the road to check into a motel. We all know what happens from there. The point is that it could have been any car pulling into that motel. Perhaps if another car had pulled in just before her, this never would have happened. It could have been your car. What makes `Psycho' one of the greatest thrillers of all time is audience identification. This is achieved through a series of point of view shots coming from the eyes of Merion, as well as an eerie score performed by Bernard Herrmann. This can be easily observed for the moment Merion gets in her car to leave town. By letting the audience look through the eyes of Merion, we the audience, essentially become her. The audience is in the mindset that we want her to get out of town unseen, and we hope that her boss doesn't think twice when he sees her on the road out of town. When the audience is introduced to the police officer, it is once again through the eyes of Merion. We feel her anxiety, and we want to get out of there just as much as she does. `Like her, we lose all power of rational control, and discover how easily a 'normal' person can lapse into a condition usually associated with neurosis' (Wood, 124). In the second half of the movie, the audience floats away from Merion, and to Norman. Although he has committed a harrowing act, we are still pulling for him to cover up each detail. For example, as he covers up the crime he committed, we see only hands mopping up the bathroom, our hands. The audience thinks, `Oh my, what have I done?' (Wood, 128). One thing that the remake of `Psycho' was able to do was let movie lovers realize how good of a film the original was. By assembling a perfect cast, interweaving a series of deep themes and ideas, as well as forcing the audience to identify, Hitchcock was able to take this simple film costing less than a million dollars and turn it into his masterpiece, as well as an all-time classic.

Title: Super Thriller!
Review:
The film Psycho is about a woman named Marion who sneaks away from her old life, after stealing a large sum of money from her employer. On her way to see her fiancé, she finds herself at the desolate Bates Motel, whose owner turns out to be the namesake for the title of the film: a psycho. After obsessing about his dead mother for so long, he psychologically turned into her persona at times. The women Norman Bates kills, were killed when his mother's persona was in charge.

The main characters are Norman Bates, and Marion Crane, portrayed by Anthony Perkins and Janet Leigh, respectively.

The overall theme of this movie seems to deal with the uncertainty of unfamiliar people. When Marion, the main character, happens to meet the socially-awkward Norman Bates, she probably couldn't have imagined getting murdered by him. The message seems to be that you can never really know if the next person you meet is truly crazy.

A movie with a similar theme is Hitchhiker, in which a person driving across the country picks up a hitchhiker, who ultimately does many sadistic things to the driver. In that movie, it was also clear that you just don't know which strangers to trust.

Perhaps the most famous scene in Psycho is the one in which Marion is stabbed to death in the shower, frequently referred to as the "shower scene", in pop culture. This scene is shot and pieced together with many short clips, all shot at different angles. The constant views at different angles make the scene more suspenseful and frightening, in my opinion. Although the attacker in the scene remains obscure, it appears to be that of a woman. Ultimately, it is revealed that Norman also dresses as "Mother", whenever he thinks he is "Mother".

Another scene that best exemplifies how crazy Norman is, is the final scene, in which he's locked up in a prison cell. "Mother" is thinking that everyone has it wrong – he wouldn't even hurt a fly! The camera closes in upon him as "Mother's" thoughts are narrated. And in the close-up of Norman, an eerie feeling is truly conveyed.

When this film was first released, I think it was a first of its kind in some aspects. I think that never before, a murder had been so graphic in a movie. Although, compared to some modern movies (such as Saw), Psycho would be considered a very mild murder film.

But in any case, I believe the film was cutting-edge for the day, and remains a classic tribute to a man who truly was "Psycho".

Title: Surpassed my expectations
Review:
So much has been written about this film that all I can do is add my own voice of approval and say that I consider it to be a masterpiece, and add a few things often overlooked or not commented on that add so much to the movie's cumulative power. It's often the little things that make a film work. Here are a few examples:

a.) The absolute realism of the first twenty minutes of so, which are so true to life that they might have come from a documentary on how people lived in America forty years ago. There isn't a false note,--or a missed one--as each vocal inflection and raised eyebrow carries great meaning even if, on the surface, not much appears to be happening.

b.) Marion and the motorcycle cop. The cop is dark and sinister in appearance, due mostly to the bright desert sun, and never takes off his sunglasses. His conduct is at all times professional; he never raises his voice, and comes across as calm and rather perceptive; and he seems truly concerned over Marion Crane's fate, though he is unaware of her actual predicament. Marion is, alas, a bad actress, and the cop sees through this, if not to the heart of the matter, yet we don't want him to follow her. Despite his appearance the cop is not the angel of death but rather Marion's last chance. Had she confessed to her crime she would have escaped the fate that awaited her; and if she had just been a little less clever, and driven more slowly, and the skies remained clear, he might have followed her to the motel and intervened on her behalf.

c.) California Charlie. John Anderson is wonderful as the fast-talking, semi-streetwise small town used car salesman. At the end of almost every other line of dialogue he seems on the verge of discovering who Marion really is, then pulls back or comes to the wrong conclusion. He senses that she is being watched by the cop; but he also wants to make a sale. The scenes at the used car lot are both highly realistic,--and perfectly acted and timed--and also a little frightening, from the opening, "I'm in no mood for trouble", to the final "hey!" just before Marion drives away. We know that something isn't right, but the problem isn't with the car lot; it's Marion's plight casts a dark shadow over all her scenes there, despite the brightest sunlight imaginable.

d.) Chitchat with Norman. Once Marion and Norman settle down for a light meal in the parlor their conversation turns to general things, and Norman is a good observer, if a bit awkward socially. Without actually lying Marion gives herself away with a throwaway line ("Sometimes just once is enough", in a reference to private traps) and Norman seems to catch her drift, if not the actual meaning of what she's saying, and allows it to pass. We can see that he is moody when he angrily leans forward and delivers an angry, though controlled tirade against putting people in institutions. Every camera angle and line of dialogue in this scene has meaning and carries enormous weight, and yet the drama plays out in a light, relaxed mode, and the performers seems truly connected to one another at its conclusion, strangers no more. This is in my opinion the best written and most beautifully acted, edited and photographed scene I have ever seen in a movie. The handling of every nuance is prodigal and masterful, and the end result nothing less than staggering.

e.) The sheriff's house. When Sam and Lila wake up the sheriff and his wife in the middle of the night we see a splendid example of people talking to one another without either party understanding what is in fact going on. The result is a mini-comedy of manners; but it is also good exposition, as we learn of Mrs. Bates' death (and the dress she was buried in, "periwinkle blue"). John McInyre's sheriff dominates this scene (and no other), and expertly delivers its punchline, "Well if that's Mrs. Bates in the window, who's that buried up in Greenlawn Cemetary".

f.) Arbogast and Norman. The private detective's interview with Norman is played low-key, and yet we sense the tension in Norman's voice and manner, and know that Arbogast does, too. Something is amiss. This is beyond the question of who killed Marion. The stakes feel very high in this sparring match, and though Norman wins on a technicality, we know that Arbogast is coming back for more.

g.) The shrink's explanation. This part of the film has been criticized by many for being a sop thrown to the audience. I disagree. After all, the movie came out in 1960, and by the standards of the time some explanation seems in order, and Dr. Simon Oakland is as good a man for the job as I can imagine. His analysis of Norman's pathology is cogent and extremely well delivered. Yet throughout his speech, with all its Freudian brilliance, the doctor offered a take on the story that we in the audience, even if we can accept it, can never be satisfied with. He can explain the character of Norman Bates rationally, but he cannot make our response to his story and its effect on us feel ultimately safe, feel somehow in control and finalized. Yes, one can put people like Norman under the microscope, and even dissect what one sees, but this doesn't stop such events as unfolded in the movie any less likely to occur. Ask Milton Arbogast.

In conclusion I'd like to say that great films are made up of outstanding little things, not just big moments or fancy effects. There is in fact nothing fancy about Psycho, which is on the surface is a somewhat plain-looking movie. Only when one looks beneath the surface does one see the teeming millions of small things,--gestures, glances, sudden changes in lighting, razor-sharp editing, and all above the refusal on the part of the director to let any one factor dominate--that we understand the meaning of the word genius, the meaning of the word creative.

Title: A great ride for a suspense movie.
Review:
When I saw for the first time this movie, I don't have any idea of what it will come, or the story in yet. Except, the obvious things like The Murderer scene, or the motel. I only know that Norman is gonna turn mad at some time (I was watching the 2nd season of Bates Motel in that time) and, by the first minutes, everything that I think was "WTF I'm I watching?" everything was so "happy" in some ways that I seriously doubt that I was watching "Psycho", but like 40 or 30 minutes later, everything just blow up my mind. The twist that Hitchcock gives to the movie in the way that he does... just another director simply cannot do it. The minutes before the "End" words appears, I admit that I feel very excited about the whole film. I was so proud of being watching that film, and so awful about don't seeing before. "Psycho" was an "after" and "before" in my movie tastes. I totally recommend it.

Title: ** Best Movie Ever!! **
Review:
Hitchcock movies are my favorite! Psycho by far is the best of all of the Hitchcock movies. I am only 47, but have been a fan of Hitchcock movies since I was 19 and saw Psycho II in the movie theater back in 1983. When I saw the black/white clip of Psycho in the beginning of the Psycho II movie, I was hooked and had to see the original that started it all. Movies today don't come close to those made by Hitchcock back then. Remakes can never match the original. The acting was tremendous. I was always a fan of Anthony Perkins' work and loved Janet Leigh as Marion Crane. The filming, the scenery, the old cars, all of it had me hooked from the beginning. Psycho is the best!

Title: There is a new master of horror

He just recently finished his second feature film "Johnny Come lately" and word of mouth is. Its scary. People are saying this new film director is reincarnated by the master himself. Johnny Come Lately is all Alfred Hitchcock. And their are rumors that Francis Xavier wants to remake "The Birds". Check out www.metpix.com and read all about this new filmmaker for the ages. It will come as no surprise to see film critics hailing this young man as the new Hitchcock. It's in the making. For years, film directors have tried, Brian DePalma is one. Title: The beginning...
Review:
This movie started it all. Since then, Hollywood made many good serial killer movies, and this here is the father of it (or should I say "Mother"). It also defined the "rules" for a good horror movie: twists; creepy, mysterious and ghostlike creatures; a sinister ending and something to think about in a psychological sense. Anthony Perkins is the inspiring source to all Norman Bates, John Does, Jason Voorhees or Michael Myers crawling beneath the surface of normal life. The other actors are okay, I guess, but the best part of the movie is really Perkins.

Overall, this movie gets 10 points of 10 from me. A true masterpiece and today almost as chilling as it was 44 years ago.

Title: A masterpiece
Review:
Hitchcock at his best! This must been one of the best suspense/thriller/ horror films i've seen. No other movie had the impact and the greatness of this. And the story behind the movie is really something, not only the book that inspired the movie but also the behind the scenes (i recommend that you take a look at the movie Hitchcock with Anthony Hopkins and Helen Mirren or read a little about it, it's very interesting). Perkins makes a terrific performance as Norman Bates (the best i've seen). Janet Leigh equally fantastic, and don't forget Vera Miles, John Gavin and the detective Arbogast (Martin Balsam) who made also a great job. Overall the movie is really something, timeless and so much better than the remakes and sequels. It's a pioneer of horror, if you are a fan of the genre or not you'll get it. Psycho is a must see for all movie lovers out there. Splendid.

Title: As devastating today as ever!!!!
Review: When I began watching this movie I felt that a film from the year 1960 couldn't possibly have an effect on somebody who has seen all the major horror movies of the last 30 years or so. Exorcist, Omen, The Shining, Friday the 13th, etc. etc. etc. etc. Never have I watched a movie that layered such powerful emotional scenarios into digestible brain food that nourishes the darkest places of my psyche. . As the movie went on I felt Norman Bates' madness slowly bubble and build so exquisitely that it was indeed a guilty pleasure to witness his final all out blitzkrieg into sheer madness. At this breaking point it was I too who had lived the moment with all of the unfortunate guests of the Bates Motel. Oh I am not a psycho per SE, but after watching this movie I felt like I lived every experience in the first person. It was after the movie directly after the last scene that I realized that a movie this special had eluded my eyes for so long. I almost felt heartbroken because it would have been the horror/terror movie to judge all others. I recommend to any teenager getting into film to really watch this, perhaps alone, perhaps not. I am just floored by the powerful use of music and the absolute shock value. The psychological thriller was born from this film. I thought SEVEN was shocking, and to some degree it was. But I was shocked deep to my core after viewing this masterpiece. Nothing in film will shock me ever again, I truly believe this. This Hitchcock fellow was something special. It took me 30 years to see this, and its much more than just a shower scene. Thats only the beginning. Oh the classics. Lets not confuse Classic with Old like so many of us are so quick to do. This movie transcends Classic and is more modern than the stuff Hollywood is pushing out these days. Still shocking after 46 years.

Title: excellent performance
Review:
An exceptional story line. the acting is also some of the best I've seen. I have recently watched the series Bates Motel which tells the story behind the motel in this original film. Also the mental state of Norman and his Mother whom has him completely under control, Norma. The role of Norman Bates was successfully filled by the young Freddy Highmore, maybe this series could prompt a remake of the film? Anthony Perkins performance was outstanding as was Vera Miles whom played Lila Crane. I would most definitely recommend this film to anyone to likes mentally stimulating film. It keeps ypu on your toes and the edge of your seat.

Title: The Best Picture of Hitchcock
Review:
Of all the films Alfred Hitchcock is the most famous, the scariest, the most unexpired, the most innovative and unique, despite countless attempts to reproduce this success. However, during the life of the Maestro, no one dared to direct the sequel, and only in 80-e years have appeared three "Psychosis" and "Psycho III" was shot by actor Anthony Perkins, who almost all his life became a kind of hostage to his role of serial killer Norman Bates. But thousands of all kinds of thrillers, chillers, suspension, shockers and other newly formed genres, efforts were made to intimidate the audience with what Hitchcock techniques. It would seem that "Psychosis" was to suffer the fate of some outstanding paintings pilfered, that is, on HR and even angles. The halo of glory around masterpieces often makes overly picky to determine their real incorruptibility. But "Psychosis" still draws from the first seconds, holds incredible tension and scares to shiver. Alfred Hitchcock was sensitive to the internal mechanism of the creation of fear and like an experienced psychiatrist, he knew of a secret nerve endings, touching whom are able to bring a state of uncontrolled psychosis, a genuine nightmare. Unlike many imitators, the "master of fear knew that fear breeds deep within us and not outside. The Director forces us to be afraid primarily of their own assumptions, conjecture, foreboding, happening fancy, just designing myself a terrible starting situation. The viewer inevitably identifies himself with a young Secretary Marion crane, caught by night in a secluded Motel. His owner Norman Bates has a secret, which unravels along with the heroine, who is in double danger, as her on suspicion of stealing money from the Bank is wanted by the police. And it is precisely the nightmare that is hidden in everyday reality, psychosis seemingly normal world — that is the main thing, the fear of the people in the tapes of Hitchcock.

In the "Psychosis" this feeling pushed to the limit, to the border territory, beyond which is the abyss of madness. And, accordingly, honed to perfection all cinematic techniques, means of artistic expression: from the brilliant to the oppressive music of Bernard Herrmann. The genuine innovations in which formal search is always meaningful, "tied up" in the story and accurately understood, still continue to strongly influence several decades later. And in the movie, as in most technical form of art, famous works, and especially, with innovative refinements, saved even harder. This film is still an absolute masterpiece of cinematic professionalism, skillful involvement of spectators in the game of fear. Incidentally, he was also among the most cash in the long career of Hitchcock (budget of $0.8 million was surpassed at the box office in forty times!), and the picture looked in the USA, over fifty million viewers.

Title: Brilliant and suspense lasts till the very end.
Review:
Unlike the thriller movies of today, this movie is different. It isn't one of those movies with the obvious ending. The suspense will keep you waiting till the very end. The ending will make your jaw drop it is that brilliant, you will watch it again and again.

If you are one of those people against black and white movies, thinking they are 'too old', give this movie a try because you would never guess what is going to happen and you will talk about it forever. Everything about this movie has been performed to it's best and the ending will leave you rendered speechless.

My favorite horror movie of all time, it is definitely worth a watch.
0 out of 0 found this helpful. Was this review helpful? Sign in to vote.
Permalink

Title: Hitchcock takes you for an enjoyable winding ride
Review:
So much has been written about this film that all I can do is add my own voice of approval and say that I consider it to be a masterpiece, and add a few things often overlooked or not commented on that add so much to the movie's cumulative power. It's often the little things that make a film work. Here are a few examples:

a.) The absolute realism of the first twenty minutes of so, which are so true to life that they might have come from a documentary on how people lived in America forty years ago. There isn't a false note,--or a missed one--as each vocal inflection and raised eyebrow carries great meaning even if, on the surface, not much appears to be happening.

b.) Marion and the motorcycle cop. The cop is dark and sinister in appearance, due mostly to the bright desert sun, and never takes off his sunglasses. His conduct is at all times professional; he never raises his voice, and comes across as calm and rather perceptive; and he seems truly concerned over Marion Crane's fate, though he is unaware of her actual predicament. Marion is, alas, a bad actress, and the cop sees through this, if not to the heart of the matter, yet we don't want him to follow her. Despite his appearance the cop is not the angel of death but rather Marion's last chance. Had she confessed to her crime she would have escaped the fate that awaited her; and if she had just been a little less clever, and driven more slowly, and the skies remained clear, he might have followed her to the motel and intervened on her behalf.

c.) California Charlie. John Anderson is wonderful as the fast-talking, semi-streetwise small town used car salesman. At the end of almost every other line of dialogue he seems on the verge of discovering who Marion really is, then pulls back or comes to the wrong conclusion. He senses that she is being watched by the cop; but he also wants to make a sale. The scenes at the used car lot are both highly realistic,--and perfectly acted and timed--and also a little frightening, from the opening, "I'm in no mood for trouble", to the final "hey!" just before Marion drives away. We know that something isn't right, but the problem isn't with the car lot; it's Marion's plight casts a dark shadow over all her scenes there, despite the brightest sunlight imaginable.

d.) Chitchat with Norman. Once Marion and Norman settle down for a light meal in the parlor their conversation turns to general things, and Norman is a good observer, if a bit awkward socially. Without actually lying Marion gives herself away with a throwaway line ("Sometimes just once is enough", in a reference to private traps) and Norman seems to catch her drift, if not the actual meaning of what she's saying, and allows it to pass. We can see that he is moody when he angrily leans forward and delivers an angry, though controlled tirade against putting people in institutions. Every camera angle and line of dialogue in this scene has meaning and carries enormous weight, and yet the drama plays out in a light, relaxed mode, and the performers seems truly connected to one another at its conclusion, strangers no more. This is in my opinion the best written and most beautifully acted, edited and photographed scene I have ever seen in a movie. The handling of every nuance is prodigal and masterful, and the end result nothing less than staggering.

e.) The sheriff's house. When Sam and Lila wake up the sheriff and his wife in the middle of the night we see a splendid example of people talking to one another without either party understanding what is in fact going on. The result is a mini-comedy of manners; but it is also good exposition, as we learn of Mrs. Bates' death (and the dress she was buried in, "periwinkle blue"). John McInyre's sheriff dominates this scene (and no other), and expertly delivers its punchline, "Well if that's Mrs. Bates in the window, who's that buried up in Greenlawn Cemetary".

f.) Arbogast and Norman. The private detective's interview with Norman is played low-key, and yet we sense the tension in Norman's voice and manner, and know that Arbogast does, too. Something is amiss. This is beyond the question of who killed Marion. The stakes feel very high in this sparring match, and though Norman wins on a technicality, we know that Arbogast is coming back for more.

g.) The shrink's explanation. This part of the film has been criticized by many for being a sop thrown to the audience. I disagree. After all, the movie came out in 1960, and by the standards of the time some explanation seems in order, and Dr. Simon Oakland is as good a man for the job as I can imagine. His analysis of Norman's pathology is cogent and extremely well delivered. Yet throughout his speech, with all its Freudian brilliance, the doctor offered a take on the story that we in the audience, even if we can accept it, can never be satisfied with. He can explain the character of Norman Bates rationally, but he cannot make our response to his story and its effect on us feel ultimately safe, feel somehow in control and finalized. Yes, one can put people like Norman under the microscope, and even dissect what one sees, but this doesn't stop such events as unfolded in the movie any less likely to occur. Ask Milton Arbogast.

In conclusion I'd like to say that great films are made up of outstanding little things, not just big moments or fancy effects. There is in fact nothing fancy about Psycho, which is on the surface is a somewhat plain-looking movie. Only when one looks beneath the surface does one see the teeming millions of small things,--gestures, glances, sudden changes in lighting, razor-sharp editing, and all above the refusal on the part of the director to let any one factor dominate--that we understand the meaning of the word genius, the meaning of the word creative.

Title: Classic Horror!
Review: An excellent classic horror flick. Hitchcock raised the bar for all horror movies without showing any blood, guts or nudity. A trailblazer for his time indeed. Hitchcock deliberately wanted "Psycho" to look like a cheap exploitation film. . . That is the mystery of why Hitchcock marred the ending of a masterpiece with a sequence that is grotesquely out of place. Whenever anyone speaks about Psycho, the first images that come to mind are those of Janet Leigh being hacked to death in the shower. The scene is so famous that even people who have not seen the movie are aware of it. Bernard Herrmann's strident, discordant music has been used in countless other movies to denote the appearance of a "psycho." The brilliance of the scene lies in the editing. Those who go frame-by-frame through it will note how much is left to the imagination. We see a knife, blood (actually chocolate syrup), water, and a woman's naked body (with certain parts strategically concealed from the camera), but only briefly is the penetration of the blade into the flesh shown*. The full horror of the murder is only hinted at on-screen. It takes the power of the viewer's imagination to fill in the blanks. Brilliant movie indeed.

Title: Great pic
Review:
Janet Leigh plays Marion Crane, a woman who is in love with a divorced man Sam Loomis. He says once he pays his ex wife off with the alimony, they'll get married. When Marion's boss asks her to put their most valued client's money, $40,000 to be exact, and bring it to the bank. She has other plans though, she takes the money for herself and flee's the city, but not before her boss sees her driving off. Shaky enough, huh? But she pulls over to get a nap in, and a police officer asks if she's OK, but she gets shaky and just wants to drive off. The policemen fallows her since she is so shaky and she ends up buying a different car. She gets caught in a giant rainstorm and pulls over to the Bates Motel.

She meets there, the owner, a pleasant and polite young man, Norman Bates. He lives in the house next to the motel with his mother. Marion checks in and Norman offers her dinner, they have a conversation mostly about his mom and Marion is concerned when she heard screams from the house that sounded like his mom. Norman gets on the defenses and asks Marion some questions as well, she says she is going to a "private island". Norman is very attracted to her, you can tell immediately, and she leaves knowing that she has to get out of the trap she set for herself back in Phoenix. As she's taking a shower before bed, a mysterious figure comes to the curtain and opens it stabbing Marion violently several times causing her to die. Norman cleans up the mess and gets rid of her body not knowing about her money and throwing that away too.

Only when one looks beneath the surface does one see the teeming millions of small things,--gestures, glances, sudden changes in lighting, razor-sharp editing, and all above the refusal on the part of the director to let any one factor dominate--that we understand the meaning of the word genius, the meaning of the word creative.

Title: Masterpiece
Review:
One of the most important films in cinema history. Alfred Hitchcock directs not only a masterpiece of the thriller/horror genre , but also of the whole world cinema.

All the actors in this film are excellent. Janeth Leigh is wonderful in her role. She is one of the most brilliant actresses who have worked with Alfred Hitchcock. In this film Anthony Perkins succeeds in being resounding, but also disturbing. Vera Miles and all the others secondary actors make great performances.

This film is also helped by Bernard Hermann's score, that makes the shower scene immortal. But in this film the protagonist is Hitchcok's direction,that succeeds in scaring and disturbing all the audience, in all times.

Title: The best movie of suspense

To me Psicosis, is one of the best suspense movies i have ever seen, along with the fear factor that comes with it. No doubt, Alfred Hitchcock is still known as the master of suspense. Psicosis has become a cult movie and the fact it is a black and white movie, it makes us to use our imagination in every detail of the movie. So we can picture our own colors at Psicosis. To conclude, I would say this a piece of art, this movie needs to be shown to everyone, from new cinema students, actors and those who love directing suspense movies.

Title: the movie is good for its time
Review:
So much has been written about this film that all I can do is add my own voice of approval and say that I consider it to be a masterpiece, and add a few things often overlooked or not commented on that add so much to the movie's cumulative power. It's often the little things that make a film work. Here are a few examples:

a.) The absolute realism of the first twenty minutes of so, which are so true to life that they might have come from a documentary on how people lived in America forty years ago. There isn't a false note,--or a missed one--as each vocal inflection and raised eyebrow carries great meaning even if, on the surface, not much appears to be happening.

b.) Marion and the motorcycle cop. The cop is dark and sinister in appearance, due mostly to the bright desert sun, and never takes off his sunglasses. His conduct is at all times professional; he never raises his voice, and comes across as calm and rather perceptive; and he seems truly concerned over Marion Crane's fate, though he is unaware of her actual predicament. Marion is, alas, a bad actress, and the cop sees through this, if not to the heart of the matter, yet we don't want him to follow her. Despite his appearance the cop is not the angel of death but rather Marion's last chance. Had she confessed to her crime she would have escaped the fate that awaited her; and if she had just been a little less clever, and driven more slowly, and the skies remained clear, he might have followed her to the motel and intervened on her behalf.

c.) California Charlie. John Anderson is wonderful as the fast-talking, semi-streetwise small town used car salesman. At the end of almost every other line of dialogue he seems on the verge of discovering who Marion really is, then pulls back or comes to the wrong conclusion. He senses that she is being watched by the cop; but he also wants to make a sale. The scenes at the used car lot are both highly realistic,--and perfectly acted and timed--and also a little frightening, from the opening, "I'm in no mood for trouble", to the final "hey!" just before Marion drives away. We know that something isn't right, but the problem isn't with the car lot; it's Marion's plight casts a dark shadow over all her scenes there, despite the brightest sunlight imaginable.

d.) Chitchat with Norman. Once Marion and Norman settle down for a light meal in the parlor their conversation turns to general things, and Norman is a good observer, if a bit awkward socially. Without actually lying Marion gives herself away with a throwaway line ("Sometimes just once is enough", in a reference to private traps) and Norman seems to catch her drift, if not the actual meaning of what she's saying, and allows it to pass. We can see that he is moody when he angrily leans forward and delivers an angry, though controlled tirade against putting people in institutions. Every camera angle and line of dialogue in this scene has meaning and carries enormous weight, and yet the drama plays out in a light, relaxed mode, and the performers seems truly connected to one another at its conclusion, strangers no more. This is in my opinion the best written and most beautifully acted, edited and photographed scene I have ever seen in a movie. The handling of every nuance is prodigal and masterful, and the end result nothing less than staggering.

e.) The sheriff's house. When Sam and Lila wake up the sheriff and his wife in the middle of the night we see a splendid example of people talking to one another without either party understanding what is in fact going on. The result is a mini-comedy of manners; but it is also good exposition, as we learn of Mrs. Bates' death (and the dress she was buried in, "periwinkle blue"). John McInyre's sheriff dominates this scene (and no other), and expertly delivers its punchline, "Well if that's Mrs. Bates in the window, who's that buried up in Greenlawn Cemetary".

f.) Arbogast and Norman. The private detective's interview with Norman is played low-key, and yet we sense the tension in Norman's voice and manner, and know that Arbogast does, too. Something is amiss. This is beyond the question of who killed Marion. The stakes feel very high in this sparring match, and though Norman wins on a technicality, we know that Arbogast is coming back for more.

g.) The shrink's explanation. This part of the film has been criticized by many for being a sop thrown to the audience. I disagree. After all, the movie came out in 1960, and by the standards of the time some explanation seems in order, and Dr. Simon Oakland is as good a man for the job as I can imagine. His analysis of Norman's pathology is cogent and extremely well delivered. Yet throughout his speech, with all its Freudian brilliance, the doctor offered a take on the story that we in the audience, even if we can accept it, can never be satisfied with. He can explain the character of Norman Bates rationally, but he cannot make our response to his story and its effect on us feel ultimately safe, feel somehow in control and finalized. Yes, one can put people like Norman under the microscope, and even dissect what one sees, but this doesn't stop such events as unfolded in the movie any less likely to occur. Ask Milton Arbogast.

In conclusion I'd like to say that great films are made up of outstanding little things, not just big moments or fancy effects. There is in fact nothing fancy about Psycho, which is on the surface is a somewhat plain-looking movie. Only when one looks beneath the surface does one see the teeming millions of small things,--gestures, glances, sudden changes in lighting, razor-sharp editing, and all above the refusal on the part of the director to let any one factor dominate--that we understand the meaning of the word genius, the meaning of the word creative.

Title: Av Productions
Review:
The movie caught my eye as we watched it but the movie in itself was outstanding. All the scary scenes,were not jumpscares like they are now. No they were more than that. Alfred Hitchcock used psychology, which i think hints the title. He uses your own imagination against you, getting into your brain and playing with your emotions. He lets your imagination run wild before he shows who was doing all these horrific things. He played the system on this one i think, knowing back then the hays code back then was just terrible. Some parts of the movie he will have you thinking and another part he will have you shaking in your boots. Back to the hays code part of this, you have to admit he did slip through the cracks a bit on this one. The code was extremely strict back then not letting homicide,suicide or even nudity be shown back then. He did not put any in there explicitly letting it be shown. Yet he did let you know what was going on in obvious ways , such as showing blood running down a drain and other things of that nature. This movie was outstanding in my opinion . Every dark vs light aspect was just right showing characters in dark clothing to be evil or crooked, and lighter colored characters to be loving and good. Even the small things like the Mcguffin he got just right in my opinion , you didn't know the importance of it until he wanted you to and that was the crazy thing about this movie, i think every actor and actress played their parts very well. Not letting the plot of the story get tangled and brought off course at all, i think this is one of the best if not the best movie of the early years of films.

-Ehvyn Baker
